abstract: Everybody talks about caregiver burnout, how you have to make time for yourself or you won’t be able to go on. But nobody talks about how burnout creeps up on you, how it starts to happen before you even realize it.
snippet: Everybody talks about caregiver burnout, how you have to make time for yourself or you won’t be able to go on. But nobody talks about how burnout creeps up on you, how it starts to happen before you even realize it.
lead_paragraph: It was time to stop working, to emerge from my home office into Mom’s world, and I was really frustrated.
headline.main: Broken, Briefly

abstract: Gary Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, defended the physical nature of professional hockey and cautioned against connecting any dots between the brain disease C.T.E. and fighting.
snippet: Gary Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, defended the physical nature of professional hockey and cautioned against connecting any dots between the brain disease C.T.E. and fighting.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — The N.H.L. board of directors met for three and a half hours Tuesday and never broached the subject of fighting, Commissioner Gary Bettman said. Fighting is an aspect of the game that has come under scrutiny by others in the wake of the recent deaths of three of the game’s enforcers.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert A. Stern, a neuropsychologist and a co-director for the Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, is answering questions Tuesday afternoon about C.T.E. and John Branch’s series “Punched Out.”

abstract: In a darkened theater, a reminder that the indignities and conflicts of old age have been with us for centuries.
snippet: In a darkened theater, a reminder that the indignities and conflicts of old age have been with us for centuries.
lead_paragraph: King Lear has problems with executive function.
headline.main: Sharper Than a Serpent’s Tooth

abstract: Researchers initiate an effort to understand how patients cope after learning they have cognitive problems.
snippet: Researchers initiate an effort to understand how patients cope after learning they have cognitive problems.
lead_paragraph: How would you react to a diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment — memory problems that allow you to continue normal daily activities, but presage an increased likelihood of developing Alzheimer’s disease within a few years?
headline.main: It’s Mild Cognitive Impairment. Now What?

abstract: Some simple steps to help elderly patients avoid hospital delirium.
snippet: Some simple steps to help elderly patients avoid hospital delirium.
lead_paragraph: My family and I watched my mother suddenly descend into delirium during her hospital stay after surgery. I can assure you that anyone who has seen somebody lose her mind within a matter of hours — even if she comes back from the dark side — doesn’t ever want to see it happen again.
headline.main: Preventing Hospital Delirium

abstract: Many members of the middle class have to look after their disabled relatives themselves, or pay someone to do it.
snippet: Many members of the middle class have to look after their disabled relatives themselves, or pay someone to do it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The law that many Americans had hoped would transform the nation’s dysfunctional system of long-term care for the swelling ranks of people with disabilities and dementia quietly died this month, a victim of its own weaknesses, a toxic political environment and President Obama’s re-election campaign focus on jobs.

abstract: The judge in the case of Liliane Bettencourt based her decision on a medical evaluation that indicated the heiress suffers from dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
snippet: The judge in the case of Liliane Bettencourt based her decision on a medical evaluation that indicated the heiress suffers from dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
lead_paragraph: Liliane Bettencourt, the aging heiress of the L’Oréal cosmetics fortune, was placed under the care of a legal guardian Monday by a judge, who based the decision on a medical evaluation that indicated she suffers from dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: French Court Puts L'Oréal Heiress Under Guardianship
headline.print_headline: France: Heiress Loses Control of Fortune

abstract: A shoe with a hidden G.P.S. device may help caregivers find wandering family members.
snippet: A shoe with a hidden G.P.S. device may help caregivers find wandering family members.
lead_paragraph: I hear from lots of publicists touting technology products that supposedly help older adults, and I ignore most of the gizmos they’re promoting. Without a skilled and unbiased Consumer Reports-type lab to test these inventions — and could someone please create one soon? — it’s too hard to tell which actually work well.
headline.main: A Shoe for Wanderers

abstract: Rick Martin, the left wing on the Sabres’ French Connection line, had chronic traumatic encephalopathy when he died last March of a heart attack at age 59.
snippet: Rick Martin, the left wing on the Sabres’ French Connection line, had chronic traumatic encephalopathy when he died last March of a heart attack at age 59.
lead_paragraph: Rick Martin, the former N.H.L. star, had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a neurodegenerative disease linked to repeated brain trauma, when he died last March of a heart attack at age 59.
headline.main: Former Star Had Disease Linked to Brain Trauma
headline.print_headline: Former Star Had Disease Linked to Brain Trauma

abstract: On Tuesday, a committee meets in Washington to begin putting together a national plan to fight Alzheimer’s disease. You are cordially invited.
snippet: On Tuesday, a committee meets in Washington to begin putting together a national plan to fight Alzheimer’s disease. You are cordially invited.
lead_paragraph: People concerned about Alzheimer’s disease and its effect on families, on the health care system, on the country as a whole, have lobbied for years for a national action plan. How should the nation confront a disease projected to afflict more than 13 million Americans by 2050 — a disease gaining on cancer as the illness Americans dread most?
headline.main: Coming Soon: A National Strategy on Alzheimer’s

abstract: An evangelist sets off a furor by suggesting that it’s appropriate to divorce a spouse with dementia.
snippet: An evangelist sets off a furor by suggesting that it’s appropriate to divorce a spouse with dementia.
lead_paragraph: The question from a viewer of “The 700 Club” had likely crossed the minds of hundreds of thousands of people experiencing the slow and inevitable loss of a spouse to Alzheimer’s disease or another dementia. Could a healthy partner justify a relationship with someone else as a demented spouse declined?

abstract: Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, said she hoped to manage the disease and planned to coach in the coming season.
snippet: Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, said she hoped to manage the disease and planned to coach in the coming season.
lead_paragraph: Pat Summitt, the longtime women’s basketball coach at Tennessee who has won more games than any other major college coach, said she forgot things at crucial points in games at times last season and struggled to keep track of when meetings were scheduled. She grew so confused that on a few days she simply stayed home from work.

abstract: In “Turn of Mind,” Alice LaPlante offers a haunting portrait of a woman suffering from dementia.
snippet: In “Turn of Mind,” Alice LaPlante offers a haunting portrait of a woman suffering from dementia.
lead_paragraph: It can’t be coincidence that as more of us confront the anguish of dementia, artists are becoming intrigued with shifting memory and altered personality, with dementia’s deeply unsettling effect on the self and on others.
headline.main: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: A Doctor’s Decline

abstract: Sleep apnea, a common condition in the elderly and overweight, was linked to memory problems and dementia in older women.
snippet: Sleep apnea, a common condition in the elderly and overweight, was linked to memory problems and dementia in older women.
lead_paragraph: Sleep-disordered breathing, or sleep apnea, is a common condition characterized by repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night. People with the disorder often snore and gasp during sleep, and it has been associated with hypertension, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Now a new study suggests it may also be associated with mental decline and dementia.
headline.main: Common Sleep Problem Raises Dementia Risk

abstract: A runny nose, fallen arches and a need to wear dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.
snippet: A runny nose, fallen arches and a need to wear dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.
lead_paragraph: A runny nose, fallen arches and dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.
headline.main: Small Health Woes Increase Dementia Risk

abstract: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance.
snippet: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance.
lead_paragraph: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance. Activity appears to be critical, though scientists have yet to prove that exercise can ward off serious problems like Alzheimer’s disease. But what about the more mundane, creeping memory loss that begins about the time our 30s recede, when car keys and people’s names evaporate? It’s not Alzheimer’s, but it’s worrying. Can activity ameliorate its slow advance — and maintain vocabulary retrieval skills, so that the word “ameliorate” leaps to mind when needed?
headline.main: How Exercise Can Keep the Brain Fit

lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND, Tex. — The potential casualties of the N.F.L.’s work stoppage include players, owners and, eventually, parking-lot attendants and many others whose work is tied to the sport. The lockout’s first victim, however, could be a former merchant seaman from Brooklyn who once worked on the Apollo lunar module but today lies inert in Room 12 at the Silverado dementia-care facility here.

abstract: Can reiki soothe elderly patients with dementia?
snippet: Can reiki soothe elderly patients with dementia?
lead_paragraph: You can see the logic. Old people with dementia can become frightened and restless, angry or agitated. Reiki, a Japanese healing practice that supposedly channels a universal energy, is said to be soothing and deeply relaxing. So why not offer reiki to elderly dementia patients?

abstract: Faced with the possibility that their parents have grown too confused to manage their own finances, many adult children turn to physicians. But often they are ill equipped to help cope with an elderly patient’s financial problems.
snippet: Faced with the possibility that their parents have grown too confused to manage their own finances, many adult children turn to physicians. But often they are ill equipped to help cope with an elderly patient’s financial problems.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Miller first became alarmed when her mother began complaining during their phone conversations. “I’m spending so much money,” she fretted. “I can’t figure out why I don’t have any money.” This was a departure: Ms. Miller’s mother, always responsible about her finances, never liked talking about them. Ms. Miller wondered what was going on.

lead_paragraph: The Times reports today on research into new ways to care for people with Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.

abstract: A group of 75 retired players alleged that teams’ mismanagement of their concussions, and the league’s willful concealment of the effects of head injuries, led to the players’ current brain damage.
snippet: A group of 75 retired players alleged that teams’ mismanagement of their concussions, and the league’s willful concealment of the effects of head injuries, led to the players’ current brain damage.
lead_paragraph: A group of 75 retired N.F.L. veterans sued the league in a California court on Tuesday, alleging that N.F.L. teams’ mismanagement of their concussions, and the league’s willful concealment of evidence of the long-term effects of head injuries, led to the players’ current brain damage.

abstract: Readers respond.
snippet: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: As a graduate student in neuroscience who studies patients with disorders of consciousness, including some who respond to zolpidem, I commend the author for accurately capturing both the desperation and the hope associated with recovery from brain injury. But I strongly object to the article’s title as it appeared on The Times’s Web site: “A Drug That Wakes the Near Dead.” Patients with disorders of consciousness like the ones profiled in the article are not near death. Such a label conflates brain injury with brain degeneration. Further, it trivializes the often heartbreaking end-of-life decisions that families make. While the article made this point, the title you chose unfortunately reinforces a false stereotype of these very much alive patients.
headline.main: Waking Chris
headline.print_headline: Waking Chris

abstract: Patients with advanced dementia often are sent to hospitals unnecessarily, according to a new report.
snippet: Patients with advanced dementia often are sent to hospitals unnecessarily, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no group of nursing home residents is more vulnerable than those with advanced dementia: unable to speak for themselves, suffering the physical as well as the cognitive effects of their terminal disease, prone to confusion or fear when subjected to blood tests or trips in screaming ambulances.
headline.main: Dementia Patients Hospitalized Too Often, Study Finds

abstract: A United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal announced Thursday that Ieng Thirith, the former minister for social affairs for the Khmer Rouge, should be unconditionally released.
snippet: A United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal announced Thursday that Ieng Thirith, the former minister for social affairs for the Khmer Rouge, should be unconditionally released.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — A tribunal backed by the United Nations that is trying top leaders of the Khmer Rouge announced on Thursday that a sister-in-law of the regime’s former leader, Pol Pot, was unfit to stand trial and should be released because she suffers from dementia.

abstract: I was thrilled that my mother wanted to move in with me. Looking back, though, I realize it was the beginning of the end of my job.
snippet: I was thrilled that my mother wanted to move in with me. Looking back, though, I realize it was the beginning of the end of my job.
lead_paragraph: I was in the middle of a business meeting when my 17-year-old son called the office and told the receptionist it was urgent.
headline.main: The Job to End All Others

abstract: Australian researchers find that elderly drivers commonly commit serious errors.
snippet: Australian researchers find that elderly drivers commonly commit serious errors.
lead_paragraph: True or false? Most older drivers drive as safely as anyone else. It’s just that a few bad apples, particularly those behind the wheel despite poor vision or dementia, make mistakes and produce the statistics showing that per mile driven, drivers over age 75 are almost as dangerous as teenagers.
headline.main: Elderly Drivers Fail a Test

abstract: I was prepared to help my mother with medical appointments, groceries, finances and more. But messing with her right to drive, I discovered, was a huge, neon-lit no-no.
snippet: I was prepared to help my mother with medical appointments, groceries, finances and more. But messing with her right to drive, I discovered, was a huge, neon-lit no-no.
lead_paragraph: Sneaking into my mother’s garage to disable the engine of her 1997 Honda Accord was not something I ever imagined doing in my role as daughter and caregiver of a parent in failing health.
headline.main: My Solution to the Driving Problem: Vandalism

abstract: A support group gives caregivers something science and doctors can’t: collective experience, a priceless resource.
snippet: A support group gives caregivers something science and doctors can’t: collective experience, a priceless resource.
lead_paragraph: Monday morning can be a downer, but for the dozen women and men in our support group, it’s a highlight of our week. That’s when we gather to speak candidly of what is unspeakable in polite society or even among closest friends and family.

abstract: “Why are we in this tunnel?” my mother asks. If you’d been with us earlier in the day, you’d never have known she has dementia.
snippet: “Why are we in this tunnel?” my mother asks. If you’d been with us earlier in the day, you’d never have known she has dementia.
lead_paragraph: “Why are we in this tunnel?” my mother asks sharply from the back seat.
headline.main: In the Dark, Maybe, but Not Lost

abstract: Elderly patients with dementia are receiving feeding tubes without families getting adequate information about the drawbacks, a new study finds.
snippet: Elderly patients with dementia are receiving feeding tubes without families getting adequate information about the drawbacks, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a few months back about one of the toughest decisions families face as their elders falter: whether to allow insertion of a feeding tube.   Somehow, this question seems to stir up even more doubt and anxiety than other medical interventions intended to prolong or improve life. When a senior nears death and cannot speak for herself, we may find it easier to say no to cardiopulmonary resuscitation or a ventilator than to say no to nutrition.
headline.main: When Demented Patients Receive Feeding Tubes

abstract: Primary progressive aphasia is one of several forms of brain disease lost in the medical shadow of a much better known relative, Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Primary progressive aphasia is one of several forms of brain disease lost in the medical shadow of a much better known relative, Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Steve Riedner of Schaumburg, Ill., was a 55-year-old tool-and-die maker, a job that involves difficult mental calculations, and a frequent speaker at community meetings when he found himself increasingly at a loss for words and unable to remember numbers. He even began to have difficulty reading his own written comments.

abstract: Dr. Gary Kennedy, a geriatric psychiatrist, on those revised medical guidelines for diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Dr. Gary Kennedy, a geriatric psychiatrist, on those revised medical guidelines for diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The newly revised criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, the first change since 1984 in how this dementia is diagnosed, are likely to be most valuable at first to scientists and researchers. The guidelines spring in part from novel research into biomarkers and imaging techniques that may not reach family medical practices for some time.
headline.main: Remaking Alzheimer’s: A Few Questions

abstract: Mr. Perry, who was known as the “Jet” throughout his career, was one of pro football’s top runners in the decade after World War II and the first to run for 1,000 yards two N.F.L. seasons in a row.
snippet: Mr. Perry, who was known as the “Jet” throughout his career, was one of pro football’s top runners in the decade after World War II and the first to run for 1,000 yards two N.F.L. seasons in a row.
lead_paragraph: Joe Perry, the San Francisco 49ers’ Hall of Fame fullback who was one of the first black stars in modern professional football, died Monday in Tempe, Ariz. He was 84.

abstract: A look at the three stages of Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: A look at the three stages of Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: ALZHEIMER’S DEMENTIA
headline.main: Stages of Alzheimer’s Disease
headline.print_headline: Stages of Disease

abstract: On Tuesday, the National Institute on Aging is releasing new medical guidelines radically recasting what it means to have Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: On Tuesday, the National Institute on Aging is releasing new medical guidelines radically recasting what it means to have Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning that for the first time in 27 years, Alzheimer’s disease is being redefined in new medical guidelines reflecting mounting evidence that the disease ravages the brain years before symptoms of dementia appear.
headline.main: Alzheimer’s, Redefined

abstract: The definition of the disease will be recast for the first time in 27 years, with a division into three stages, including a new early phase.
snippet: The definition of the disease will be recast for the first time in 27 years, with a division into three stages, including a new early phase.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 27 years, the definition of Alzheimer’s disease is being recast in new medical guidelines that reflect fast-mounting evidence that it begins ravaging the brain years before the symptoms of dementia.
headline.main: Guidelines Allow Earlier Definition of Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: New Guidelines Offered To Diagnose Alzheimer’s

abstract: I wonder if my mother’s sudden anger is a form of “sundowning.”
snippet: I wonder if my mother’s sudden anger is a form of “sundowning.”
lead_paragraph: I am lying in my bed reading when there is a distant rat-ta-tat. It is after 11:30 p.m.
headline.main: What the Night Brings

abstract: Experts are always urging family members to “redirect” people with dementia, rather than point out their errors or argue with them. Sometimes that’s not so easy.
snippet: Experts are always urging family members to “redirect” people with dementia, rather than point out their errors or argue with them. Sometimes that’s not so easy.
lead_paragraph: Leila Arnett, 94, moved into a nursing home in Louisville, Ky., last summer. She’s having a hard time — congestive heart failure, aortic stenosis, trouble hearing and seeing, general frailty. She recognizes visiting family members and can make conversation, but her dementia is causing delusions.
headline.main: Packing Away a Delusion

abstract: With a little help, my mother remembered my birthday. But what if one day she cannot remember me?
snippet: With a little help, my mother remembered my birthday. But what if one day she cannot remember me?
lead_paragraph: When I got up, Mom was already awake. I could hear her rummaging in the kitchen. Through the glass doors in the living room, sunlight flared so brightly off the hillocks of snow that I had to shield my eyes.
headline.main: Forgetting the Gift

abstract: In a major shift in attitude that reflects the challenges of an aging population, China is starting to publicly confront dementia.
snippet: In a major shift in attitude that reflects the challenges of an aging population, China is starting to publicly confront dementia.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Last year, an expensive, red-brick residential complex opened here, equipped with a hair salon, cinema, toy-cluttered game rooms and a karaoke suite offering the latest in pop music.

abstract: She can’t remember exactly where we are; she can’t remember exactly where we’re going. But having lost the thread, she still relishes the count.
snippet: She can’t remember exactly where we are; she can’t remember exactly where we’re going. But having lost the thread, she still relishes the count.
lead_paragraph: We are driving in silence along the road near my house when I hear my mother counting. I am hunched over the wheel, gnawing the inside of my lip, plotting how I am going to pay this winter’s heating bill while Mom strains against her seat belt, craning her neck, whispering: Three! Four! Five!
headline.main: Counting Her Blessings

abstract: A Phoenix nursing home has found that unlimited chocolate, and other comforts, go a long way in reducing patients’ distress.
snippet: A Phoenix nursing home has found that unlimited chocolate, and other comforts, go a long way in reducing patients’ distress.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Margaret Nance was, to put it mildly, a difficult case. Agitated, combative, often reluctant to eat, she would hit staff members and fellow residents at nursing homes, several of which kicked her out. But when Beatitudes nursing home agreed to an urgent plea to accept her, all that changed.

abstract: The tragic side of pro football is increasingly emerging from the shadows.

snippet: A report found that dementia patients in nursing homes were often given prescriptions improperly.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one in seven elderly nursing home residents, nearly all of them with dementia, are given powerful atypical antipsychotic drugs even though the medicines increase the risks of death and are not approved for such treatments, a government audit found.

abstract: The test was a crucial first step in the development of so-called neuroprosthetic devices to repair deficits from dementia, stroke and other brain injuries in humans.
snippet: The test was a crucial first step in the development of so-called neuroprosthetic devices to repair deficits from dementia, stroke and other brain injuries in humans.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have designed a brain implant that restored lost memory function and strengthened recall of new information in laboratory rats — a crucial first step in the development of so-called neuroprosthetic devices to repair deficits from dementia, stroke and other brain injuries in humans.
headline.main: Memory Implant Gives Rats Sharper Recollection

abstract: Researchers on Tuesday reported progress toward the development of two tests to screen adults for Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Researchers on Tuesday reported progress toward the development of two tests to screen adults for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have made further progress on two tests designed to detect Alzheimer’s disease, The Times reported on Tuesday. An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration this week will determine whether one of these tests, a brain scan, should be marketed for widespread use. The other screening tool, a blood test, is still in the earliest stages of development.
headline.main: Screening for Alzheimer’s

abstract: Margene, who is getting deeper into the crazy pyramid scheme that is Goji juice, has become the spokeswoman of an increasingly troubled family.
snippet: Margene, who is getting deeper into the crazy pyramid scheme that is Goji juice, has become the spokeswoman of an increasingly troubled family.
lead_paragraph: “I’m the sunny face of polygamy.” Let’s just acknowledge that this line, delivered by Margene, was surely the best of Sunday’s episode of “Big Love.” Margene, who is getting deeper into the crazy pyramid scheme that is Goji juice, has also become the spokeswoman for a family increasingly in crisis. But before we get to that and the impending divorce proceedings, I have a bone to pick with the haphazard unfolding of the episode. The matter of Alby hiring Verland to attack Don during his ice fishing trip felt random and pointless. This is the best way the writers could think of for Alby’s getting back at Bill for getting Lura away from him? Even as the scene was transpiring it seemed as if the writers were doing it on a lark and were fully conscious that the plotting was arbitrary and almost jokey. (The jaunty music accompanying the attack made this especially clear.)Also: Bill’s mother’s dementia isn’t feeling fully integrated either. Her dementia may be relevant to the season’s theme of the Henricksons’ general deterioration, but beyond that symbolic value, it’s hard to see how Lois’s condition will matter much to the final outcome of the show. Another plot development that felt half-baked was the sudden turnaround of Bill’s fate at the legislature. The tabling of the impeachment felt way too abrupt.
headline.main: ‘Big Love’ Watch: A Family in Crisis

abstract: In Minnesota, nursing home residents are weaned from psychotropic drugs in an experimental effort to reconnect them to the world.
snippet: In Minnesota, nursing home residents are weaned from psychotropic drugs in an experimental effort to reconnect them to the world.
lead_paragraph: The woman, who was in her 90s, had lived for several years at the Ecumen Sunrise nursing home in Two Harbors, Minn., where the staff had grown accustomed to her grimaces and wordless cries. She took a potent cocktail of three psychotropic drugs: Ativan for anxiety and the antipsychotic Risperdal to calm her, plus an antidepressant. In all the time she’d lived at Sunrise, she hadn’t spoken. It wasn’t clear whether she could recognize her children when they came to visit.
headline.main: Clearing the Fog in Nursing Homes

abstract: Scientists have calculated that if people address certain risks, a significant number of Alzheimer’s cases could be prevented, with the operative word being “could.”
snippet: Scientists have calculated that if people address certain risks, a significant number of Alzheimer’s cases could be prevented, with the operative word being “could.”
lead_paragraph: Is there a way to prevent Alzheimer’s disease? Last week, a study presented at the Alzheimer’s Association International Conference in Paris suggested there might be, something that would give hope to millions who worry that one day they may be struggling with dementia.
headline.main: Grasping for Any Way to Prevent Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: Grasping for Any Way To Prevent Alzheimer’s

abstract: After analyzing the genes of more than 50,000 people in the United States and Europe, researchers discover five genes that make Alzheimer’s somewhat more likely in the elderly.
snippet: After analyzing the genes of more than 50,000 people in the United States and Europe, researchers discover five genes that make Alzheimer’s somewhat more likely in the elderly.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning that two enormous studies have linked five genes to the development of Alzheimer’s disease. The associations are not strong — each gene confers an increase in risk of just 10 to 15 percent — but they should help point researchers to new mechanisms underlying this dementia.
headline.main: Scientists Link New Genes to Alzheimer’s

abstract: When is it OK for caregivers to fib?
snippet: When is it OK for caregivers to fib?
lead_paragraph: My friend Roberta has been looking after her mother for years. She’s been concealing the truth from her for years, too. Roberta’s mother is pretty healthy at age 92, exuberantly odd but lucid — “wildly wrong about many things, but she’s not demented,” her daughter told me. But she’s prone to periods of severe anxiety, which then produce stomach pain and indigestion.
headline.main: White Lies and Worse

lead_paragraph: Joseph Selame, who created a wide array of familiar logos and brand identities for dozens of companies and nonprofit organizations, including Apple Bank, Goodwill Industries, Kodak and CVS Pharmacy, died on March 29 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 86.

abstract: A government audit finds that nearly one in seven nursing home residents receives powerful antipsychotic drugs, though they are not approved for such use.
snippet: A government audit finds that nearly one in seven nursing home residents receives powerful antipsychotic drugs, though they are not approved for such use.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today that that nearly one in seven elderly nursing home residents, almost all of them with dementia, are given powerful atypical antipsychotic drugs even though the medicines increase the risk of death and are not approved for such treatments, a government audit found.
headline.main: Antipsychotics Overused in Nursing Homes, Audit Finds

abstract: For millions with a neurological condition called mild cognitive impairment, lapses in word-finding and name recall are often common.
snippet: For millions with a neurological condition called mild cognitive impairment, lapses in word-finding and name recall are often common.
lead_paragraph: Who hasn’t struggled occasionally to come up with a desired word or the name of someone near and dear? I was still in my 40s when one day the first name of my stepmother of 30-odd years suddenly escaped me. I had to introduce her to a friend as “Mrs. Brody.”

abstract: An early riser, the Rev. Al Sharpton recites poetry for inspiration, hops on the treadmill, does two radio shows and preaches church services around town.
snippet: An early riser, the Rev. Al Sharpton recites poetry for inspiration, hops on the treadmill, does two radio shows and preaches church services around town.
lead_paragraph: Unmistakable and formidable, if a physically reduced version of the man he once was, the Rev. Al Sharpton, 56, uses Sundays as his “half-down day.” It’s a workday, for sure — including two hourlong radio broadcasts — but it also offers chances for decompression, companionship, exercise, sending texts and posting on Twitter. A Brooklyn native, Mr. Sharpton lives in a two-bedroom apartment in the West 70s in Manhattan. —DAVID M. HALBFINGER

abstract: At 92, Mom still laughs readily, especially at herself, still dances a few steps whenever she hears jazz. She just can’t remember anything.
snippet: At 92, Mom still laughs readily, especially at herself, still dances a few steps whenever she hears jazz. She just can’t remember anything.
lead_paragraph: I stagger from my bedroom at the usual hour, careful to catch the door with my foot so it won’t bang, and head for the coffee pot. The windows are still dark.
headline.main: The Agenda for Today

abstract: For Nathan Weiner, 82, and Robert Bartlett, 78, brothers-in-law who count on each other’s company, sickness and old age threaten their way of life.
snippet: For Nathan Weiner, 82, and Robert Bartlett, 78, brothers-in-law who count on each other’s company, sickness and old age threaten their way of life.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Wiener, 82, and Robert Bartlett, 78, are soul mates.

abstract: My conflict was part of the strange and inevitable burden of responsibility that moves in with an aging parent. I wanted to respect my mother’s autonomy, yet the borders of her disability kept shifting.
snippet: My conflict was part of the strange and inevitable burden of responsibility that moves in with an aging parent. I wanted to respect my mother’s autonomy, yet the borders of her disability kept shifting.
lead_paragraph: My mother had just completed her first physical in about seven years. The new physician was young, energetic and articulate. His respectful handling of my 92-year-old mother had already earned my trust. Mom, who has a pacemaker and vascular dementia, is proud and easily insulted.
headline.main: The Uncertain Life

abstract: Dismemberment, dementia, wails of anguish, pustulant aliens: if that’s your sort of thing, Dead Space 2 is fabulous.
snippet: Dismemberment, dementia, wails of anguish, pustulant aliens: if that’s your sort of thing, Dead Space 2 is fabulous.
lead_paragraph: Is there a place in mass entertainment for dismemberment, dementia, wails of anguish and the infernal corruption of children? Is there a place for a vision of future humanity in the grip of an eldritch religion that sees salvation in alien mutation? Is there a place for titillation in the form of gore, for human (and once-human) offal as an acceptable form of set decoration?

abstract: Other Christian leaders condemned Pat Robertson for suggesting that a man may divorce his wife if she has Alzheimer’s, while some caregivers were more understanding.
snippet: Other Christian leaders condemned Pat Robertson for suggesting that a man may divorce his wife if she has Alzheimer’s, while some caregivers were more understanding.
lead_paragraph: With his suggestion this week that a man whose wife was far “gone” with Alzheimer’s should divorce her if he wanted a new companion, the television evangelist Pat Robertson stumbled into treacherous moral terrain, setting off storms of criticism and questions about a disease that shatters lives and families.

abstract: An American-born sociologist, who teaches in the school of health and social care at Bournemouth University in Britain, creates characters that are composites based on his research in rural Britain.
snippet: An American-born sociologist, who teaches in the school of health and social care at Bournemouth University in Britain, creates characters that are composites based on his research in rural Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kip Jones hates PowerPoint presentations. He doesn’t care much for academic journals, either. An American-born sociologist, who teaches in the school of health and social care at Bournemouth University in England, Mr. Jones says that “the shame of research is that you spend a lot of money and the knowledge just disappears — or worse, ends up as an article in a scholarly journal.”
headline.main: Shunning the Journals, Scholar Brings Work on Older Gays to Life in Film
headline.print_headline: Shunning the Journals, Scholar Brings Work on Older Gays to Life in Film

abstract: Three Belgian septuagenarians look to resurrect their old singing group in the dramedy “The Over the Hill Band.”
snippet: Three Belgian septuagenarians look to resurrect their old singing group in the dramedy “The Over the Hill Band.”
lead_paragraph: Lodged firmly in the “You go granny!” genre alongside wrinkled fluffery like “Calendar Girls” and the execrable “Boynton Beach Club,” “The Over the Hill Band” at least offers truth in advertising. Following three Belgian septuagenarians as they attempt to resurrect their singing group from half a century earlier, this drippy dramedy embraces every inappropriate-oldster cliché with depressing calculation.
headline.main: Like Old Times
headline.kicker: Movie Review | 'The Over the Hill Band'

abstract: Susan Jacoby challenges the optimistic marketing that has made old age seem pleasant and carefree.
snippet: Susan Jacoby challenges the optimistic marketing that has made old age seem pleasant and carefree.
lead_paragraph: Susan Jacoby has long made it her project to uncover ill-formed, cynical “junk thought” and administer a cold dose of reason and logic against it. But Jacoby is no Mr. Spock. Her rationalism is delivered in an angry barrage peppered with enthusiastically snide asides. In previous books, including “The Age of American Unreason” and “Freethinkers,” her targets have been right-leaning religionists, social Darwinists, and the paucity of reason in a generation that stares too much at glowing screens and too little at learned books. In her latest jeremiad, “Never Say Die,” she fights to slay the conspiracies of ignorance and greed that she believes conceal a single, and indeed irrefutable, truth: extreme old age can be nasty, brutish and long.

abstract: As dementia was setting in, Reagan wanted to see his childhood home, and asked his biographer to come along.
snippet: As dementia was setting in, Reagan wanted to see his childhood home, and asked his biographer to come along.
lead_paragraph: BACK in 1992, when Ronald Reagan first began to be strange (a bewilderment in his amethyst gaze, a hesitancy in speech and step), he impulsively said that he wanted to visit his birthplace. This desire was a surprise to those around the former president. He had never shown any interest in Tampico, Ill.

abstract: “A Beautiful Life,” starring Shu Qi and Liu Ye, is a contemporary romantic melodrama.
snippet: “A Beautiful Life,” starring Shu Qi and Liu Ye, is a contemporary romantic melodrama.
lead_paragraph: Among the steady stream of new Chinese movies opening in America, “A Beautiful Life” stands out — rather than an overstuffed, jingoistic historical tale or martial-arts blowout, it’s a contemporary romantic melodrama with a plaintive pop soundtrack that might call to mind “Terms of Endearment,” “The Other Sister” or, most strongly, a Nora Ephron comedy minus most of the laughs. (There’s also a bit of “Memento” thrown in.)

abstract: New York’s highest court should not permit the state to deny compensation to a man who served nine years in prison for a murder he did not commit.
snippet: New York’s highest court should not permit the state to deny compensation to a man who served nine years in prison for a murder he did not commit.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Warney, a person of limited mental capabilities who has been diagnosed with AIDS and AIDS dementia, served nine years in New York State prisons for a murder he did not commit. Now the state is seeking to compound the injustice by denying Mr. Warney compensation, even though there is a state law to provide redress for people who are wrongly convicted. New York’s highest court, which is considering his case, should not permit it.

abstract: The choreographer Muna Tseng pays homage to her mother in “Stella.”
snippet: The choreographer Muna Tseng pays homage to her mother in “Stella.”
lead_paragraph: In 1999 the choreographer Muna Tseng paid homage to her brother, the photographer Tseng Kwong Chi, who had died of AIDS. That work, “SlutForArt,” was created in collaboration with the theater artist Ping Chong. Now, in “Stella,” Ms. Tseng tries to get under the skin of her mother, a stylish woman who had a sharp tongue. Stella cared about clothes — included in the show is an exhibition of her luxurious couture dresses — and said memorable things like, “The biggest waste in life is time.”

abstract: An assisted living facility in New Mexico attempted to evict an elderly couple who chose to end their lives, according to the couple’s family.
snippet: An assisted living facility in New Mexico attempted to evict an elderly couple who chose to end their lives, according to the couple’s family.
lead_paragraph: Armond and Dorothy Rudolph had talked about their plans for more than a decade. They had a mutual horror of a lingering decline in their final years. They’d joined an organization that supports the right to end life when illness or pain becomes overwhelming; they’d attended meetings and given both their children literature on the subject. They’d drafted advance directives.

abstract: In organizing the first Willem de Kooning retrospective in three decades, curators went on an art history treasure hunt.
snippet: In organizing the first Willem de Kooning retrospective in three decades, curators went on an art history treasure hunt.
lead_paragraph: The first thing visitors will see at the entrance to the Museum of Modern Art’s sprawling Willem de Kooning retrospective, which opens on Sunday, is a wall of photographs that chronicle six stages in the creation of the legendary painting “Woman I” (1950-52). John Elderfield, MoMA’s chief curator emeritus of painting and sculpture, said he chose these images as a starting point because they illustrate “that de Kooning was an artist about process.”

abstract: The elderly are often excluded from important clinical trials, a new study finds.
snippet: The elderly are often excluded from important clinical trials, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: The randomized clinical trial, long the gold standard of medical research, supposedly provides the most reliable data regarding which drugs, devices and procedures prove effective on real patients and which don’t. But when the people enrolled in the trial are quite different from those who will actually use the drug or device or undergo the procedure, the data are far less reliable.
headline.main: Clinical Trials Neglect the Elderly

abstract: “Shelebration!,” a concert tribute to Shel Silverstein at SummerStage, pulled together some of the strands of the songwriter-author-illustrator’s diverse career.
snippet: “Shelebration!,” a concert tribute to Shel Silverstein at SummerStage, pulled together some of the strands of the songwriter-author-illustrator’s diverse career.
lead_paragraph: Dan Zanes started “Shelebration!,” a concert tribute to Shel Silverstein on Saturday night at SummerStage, with “You’re Always Welcome at Our House.” It’s a smiley, bouncy song that could be a children’s ditty except that it’s about serial murder, with a new victim in each verse. It was a canny choice that pulled together some of the many strands of Silverstein’s career.

abstract: Jim Brown has played many roles in his 60 years in the public spotlight. He has added plaintiff, in a lawsuit against Electronic Arts for portraying him on the 1965 Cleveland Browns team in the Madden video-game series.
snippet: Jim Brown has played many roles in his 60 years in the public spotlight. He has added plaintiff, in a lawsuit against Electronic Arts for portraying him on the 1965 Cleveland Browns team in the Madden video-game series.
lead_paragraph: Jim Brown has played many roles in his 60 years in the public spotlight: football star, lacrosse legend (some consider him the best lacrosse player ever), actor, social activist and more. He has added plaintiff, in a lawsuit against Electronic Arts for portraying him — not by name or face, but by weight, height, years in the league, skill rating and skin color — on the 1965 Cleveland Browns team in the Madden video-game series. The suit was dismissed in district court but is being considered by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Brown, 75, spoke by phone about the case, the lockout and his wearing yet another hat: pole-vaulter.
headline.main: 30 Seconds With Jim Brown

abstract: Larry Jones stopped training horses two years ago, but renewed health and a star filly, Havre de Grace, have him in the Breeders’ Cup Classic.

lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Two years ago Larry Jones pulled his white cowboy hat over his eyes and rode off the racetrack and into the sunset, swearing he was done training horses. abstract: Isa Leshko, a fine art photographer, set out to capture glimpses of animals in their twilight years — a therapeutic project inspired by caring for her mother with Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Isa Leshko, a fine art photographer, set out to capture glimpses of animals in their twilight years — a therapeutic project inspired by caring for her mother with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: It is not hard to argue that we live in a youth-centric culture, one in which young age and beauty are almost synonymous. And that obsession does not end with humans. Puppies and kittens melt hearts; images and videos of baby animals flood the Internet. But rarely does an image of an animal in old age ignite the same interest and adoration.
headline.main: What We Can Learn From Old Animals

lead_paragraph: Robert Morris, a cryptographer who helped develop the Unix computer operating system, which controls an increasing number of the world’s computers and touches almost every aspect of modern life, died on Sunday in Lebanon, N.H. He was 78.

abstract: The line between being a forceful advocate for your parent and being an intrusive busybody can be difficult to draw.
snippet: The line between being a forceful advocate for your parent and being an intrusive busybody can be difficult to draw.
lead_paragraph: My dad, Murray, is a chatty, gregarious guy — so I told the dining room manager when she stopped by on Day 1 at his new independent living apartment. This facility uses assigned seating at mealtimes, and I wanted his companions to be lively and stimulating.
headline.main: When to Back Off?

abstract: If we allow that the right to die exists, the arguments for confining it to the dying seem arbitrary at best.
snippet: If we allow that the right to die exists, the arguments for confining it to the dying seem arbitrary at best.
lead_paragraph: The case for assisted suicide seems to depend on human sympathy — on the impulse toward mercy, the desire to ease what seems like pointless pain and suffering. Why shouldn’t the terminally ill meet death on their own terms, rather than at the end of prolonged agonies? Why shouldn’t the dying depart this earth with dignity, instead of enduring the inexorable stripping away of their physical and mental faculties?

headline.main: Dr. Kevorkian’s Victims
headline.print_headline: Dr. Kevorkian’s Victims

abstract: The former Bears star Dave Duerson sent text messages asking that his brain tissue be tested for a chronic disease before shooting himself in the chest.
snippet: The former Bears star Dave Duerson sent text messages asking that his brain tissue be tested for a chronic disease before shooting himself in the chest.
lead_paragraph: Before he shot himself fatally in the chest Thursday, the former Chicago Bears defensive back Dave Duerson sent family members text messages requesting that his brain tissue be examined for the same damage recently found in other retired players, two people aware of the messages said Saturday night.

abstract: What happens when elderly patients are told that death is imminent.
snippet: What happens when elderly patients are told that death is imminent.
lead_paragraph: At Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, where she’s a medical director, Dr. Joan Teno has grown accustomed to patients being admitted with no clear understanding of their condition or prognosis. “The oncologist has told them, ‘It’s time to take a holiday from chemo,’” she said. “It’s a way not to have a conversation he or she finds hard to do.”
headline.main: A Conversation Many Doctors Won’t Have

abstract: The terrible disaster has changed the Japanese, but not always for the worse.
snippet: The terrible disaster has changed the Japanese, but not always for the worse.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A surreal chorus of clipped buzzing noises pierced the silence on my rush hour commuter train one morning this week. It was the earthquake warning alarms of the passengers’ cellphones indicating that another temblor was imminent.
headline.main: A Month After the Shock, a Different Japan

abstract: The joint bank account is “everybody’s default estate-planning tool,” says one expert. But an alternative type of account, more useful to caregiving children and their parents, usually is available.
snippet: The joint bank account is “everybody’s default estate-planning tool,” says one expert. But an alternative type of account, more useful to caregiving children and their parents, usually is available.
lead_paragraph: In a recent post about the sometimes contentious issue of protecting seniors who are losing the ability to manage their finances, I wrote about a daughter who was able to intervene in her mother’s financial exploitation because she was a co-signer on her bank accounts.
headline.main: A Better Bank Account

abstract: Caregiving obligations are deeply felt in many Hispanic families, but tradition is running up against harsh modern realities, experts say.
snippet: Caregiving obligations are deeply felt in many Hispanic families, but tradition is running up against harsh modern realities, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Fabiola Santiago lives in the Miami suburbs, two miles from her 81-year-old mother and 87-year-old father, whom she looks after. As the single mother of three grown daughters, she might live in the city or in Miami Beach if she had no family responsibilities — but to her, that’s like saying she’d fly if she woke up tomorrow with wings. It’s a fantasy.
headline.main: Strains for Hispanic Caregivers

abstract: In “A Separation,” Iran’s candidate for a foreign-language Oscar, a middle-class Tehran couple’s disagreement over where and how to live leads to growing chaos.
snippet: In “A Separation,” Iran’s candidate for a foreign-language Oscar, a middle-class Tehran couple’s disagreement over where and how to live leads to growing chaos.
lead_paragraph: “A Separation,” a tightly structured, emotionally astute new film from Iran, begins with a couple, at odds and in distress, arguing in front of a judge. Simin (Leila Hatami) wants to leave the country with her daughter, Termeh (Sarina Farhadi), and Simin’s husband, Nader (Peyman Moadi), insists on staying at home in Tehran to care for his frail and elderly father, who suffers from dementia and needs constant attention. Quite possibly there is more at issue than practical domestic arrangements — there are hints of suppressed anger in Nader’s demeanor, of long-simmering exasperation in Simin’s — but an Iranian courtroom may not be the best place to discuss intimate marital matters.

abstract: At Saint Ann’s School in Brooklyn, Mr. Bosworth’s expansive, scampish personality was stamped everywhere, so much so that it was common to speak of a cult of personality there.
snippet: At Saint Ann’s School in Brooklyn, Mr. Bosworth’s expansive, scampish personality was stamped everywhere, so much so that it was common to speak of a cult of personality there.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Bosworth, a self-described “old wizard” who shaped his own Hogwarts in Brooklyn in the form of Saint Ann’s School, which rapidly gained national prominence for its free-form approach to education and its success in sending graduates to top colleges, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83.

abstract: Will Scheffer, a creator of the HBO series “Big Love,” speaks about his new play, which is also about family — though a very different kind of family.
snippet: Will Scheffer, a creator of the HBO series “Big Love,” speaks about his new play, which is also about family — though a very different kind of family.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Summer Shorts series at the 59E59 Theaters includes new works by playwrights ranging from established talents (Christopher Durang and Tina Howe) to an incoming freshman at Yale (Ruby Rae Spiegel). Running in the program’s Series B is a new drama by Will Scheffer, a creator of the acclaimed television series “Big Love,” which came to its conclusion this year. Titled “The Green Book,” Mr. Scheffer’s play, which opened Thursday, deals with a Queens family. We chatted Friday about the play, families and TV projects to come. Here are excerpts:

abstract: Forrest Blue, one of the N.F.L.’s best centers of the early 1970s, died last week.
snippet: Forrest Blue, one of the N.F.L.’s best centers of the early 1970s, died last week.
lead_paragraph: A few thoughts about Forrest Blue, one of the N.F.L.’s best centers of the early 1970s. Blue was residing at an assisted-living facility in Carmichael, Calif., when he died last week at age 65 or 66 (There is some discrepancy as to whether he was born in 1944 or in 1945.) According to his daughter, Blue began exhibiting symptoms of dementia about 15 years ago. His brain will be sent to Boston University for further study. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.
headline.main: Forrest Blue, and Giving Offensive Linemen Their Due

abstract: Ali Smith’s new novel, “There but for the,” plays with words and symbols in explaining a man unseen for most of the book, and to say something about loss and retention.
snippet: Ali Smith’s new novel, “There but for the,” plays with words and symbols in explaining a man unseen for most of the book, and to say something about loss and retention.
lead_paragraph: Symbol alert! Ali Smith’s new novel opens with a perplexing prologue: a story within a story about a man on an exercise bike whose eyes and mouth are covered by what look like mailbox flaps. A small boy appears, jimmies the flaps off with a dinner knife and instructs the man in how to make a paper airplane. The man complies and discovers that “outside, on its top, it looks like a plain folded piece of paper. Inside, underneath, it is packed tight into itself with surprising neatness like origami, like a small machine.”

abstract: Hospitals nationwide are trying to redefine the E.R. experience for the elderly by building facilities dedicated solely to their needs.
snippet: Hospitals nationwide are trying to redefine the E.R. experience for the elderly by building facilities dedicated solely to their needs.
lead_paragraph: When Harold Richards, 81, arrived at the hospital emergency room in Ann Arbor, Mich., he expected a long wait. After all, he’d been through the emergency room drill before. The patient in the worst condition would be seen first, he knew, and the waiting time could be indeterminable. The rush, the harsh lights, the white walls and bright floors — everything about the place seemed designed to confuse and frighten elderly patients like him.
headline.main: Emergency Rooms Built With the Elderly in Mind
byline.original: By Alyson Martin and Nushin Rashidian

abstract: This haunting first novel’s deeply unreliable narrator is a former surgeon with Alzheimer’s and the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder.
snippet: This haunting first novel’s deeply unreliable narrator is a former surgeon with Alzheimer’s and the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Unreliable narrators come in many shapes. There are madmen, mystics, seducers, naïfs — Nabokov’s Humbert Humbert, the ghost-prone governess in “The Turn of the Screw” and Poe’s self-defeating paranoiac in “The Tell-Tale Heart,” for starters. And then there is Dr. Jennifer White, who narrates Alice LaPlante’s first novel. By the time “Turn of Mind” begins, she is losing her wits to Alzheimer’s disease and is the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder. She is as unreliable as they come.

abstract: Thousands of runners descended on 74th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, as part of a minor rerouting of the course.
snippet: Thousands of runners descended on 74th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, as part of a minor rerouting of the course.
lead_paragraph: Most of the time what passes for excitement on 74th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is figuring out which neighbor will get to feed a lurking stray white cat.

abstract: Residents of ElderSpirit, a senior cohousing venture in Virginia, have built a community where neighbors know one another, share weekly meals and help in times of need.
snippet: Residents of ElderSpirit, a senior cohousing venture in Virginia, have built a community where neighbors know one another, share weekly meals and help in times of need.
lead_paragraph: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grassroots versions — do-it-yourself senior living that’s friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. Fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are posting video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior cohousing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.
headline.main: Shared Meals, and Lives

abstract: What happens to bullies? Some of them become old bullies.
snippet: What happens to bullies? Some of them become old bullies.
lead_paragraph: When Rhea Basroon’s mother moved into a New Jersey assisted living facility a few years ago, she found a good friend in an new neighbor named Irene. Her daughters, long concerned that their widowed mother had become isolated and depressed, were initially delighted.
headline.main: Mean Girls in Assisted Living

abstract: Robert Loggia stars as the dying patriarch of a Connecticut clan in “Harvest,” a meticulously written and exquisitely acted film.
snippet: Robert Loggia stars as the dying patriarch of a Connecticut clan in “Harvest,” a meticulously written and exquisitely acted film.
lead_paragraph: “The one thing in life that really matters is family.” So declares Siv Monopoli (Robert Loggia), the dying 83-year-old patriarch of a southern Connecticut clan, to his grandson Josh (Jack T. Carpenter), in Marc Meyers’s film “Harvest.” When feeling his oats, Siv, a burly World War II veteran with a guilty secret, likes to announce that he is “cooking with gas,” but now there is almost none left.

abstract: A committee voted that the agency approve the first test that can show Alzheimer’s in the brain of a living person.
snippet: A committee voted that the agency approve the first test that can show Alzheimer’s in the brain of a living person.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test  a brain scan  that can show the characteristic plaques of Alzheimer’s disease in the brain of a living person. The approval was contingent on radiologists agreeing on what the scans say and doctors being trained in how to read the scans.

abstract: Ms. Bloom was responsible for converting an old coffee barge into a floating stage and one of the more magical places in New York’s classical music scene.
snippet: Ms. Bloom was responsible for converting an old coffee barge into a floating stage and one of the more magical places in New York’s classical music scene.
lead_paragraph: If music can salve the soul, imagine hearing it accompanied by the balm of a river’s undulations, the twinkle of the Manhattan skyline, the soothing flow of river traffic. Audiences at Bargemusic, the city’s floating concert hall moored at Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, have that experience several nights a week. It is one of the more magical places on the classical music scene and, for that matter, in all of New York.

abstract: Researchers are exploring a somewhat controversial link between minor, or subclinical, thyroid problems and some patients’ psychiatric difficulties.
snippet: Researchers are exploring a somewhat controversial link between minor, or subclinical, thyroid problems and some patients’ psychiatric difficulties.
lead_paragraph: In patients with depression, anxiety and other psychiatric problems, doctors often find abnormal blood levels of thyroid hormone. Treating the problem, they have found, can lead to improvements in mood, memory and cognition.

abstract: In the fourth novel of an unorthodox mystery series, the ex-P.I. Jackson Brodie searches for a missing woman.
snippet: In the fourth novel of an unorthodox mystery series, the ex-P.I. Jackson Brodie searches for a missing woman.
lead_paragraph: It’s West Yorkshire not long before the Yorkshire Ripper starts his killing spree, and two police officers make a grisly discovery. Behind a locked door in a block of flats lies the decomposing body of a woman. But that’s not the worst of it. The worst of it is there’s a child locked in with her, “filthy, nothing but skin and bone,” looking “like a famine victim.”

abstract: One man’s exit from a nursing home.
snippet: One man’s exit from a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: In January, when he was only 91, Edwin Murphy awoke in a hospital in Albuquerque, N.M., and learned that he’d had a heart attack.
headline.main: The Nursing Home Exodus, Part 2

abstract: At a trial scheduled to begin Monday in Cambodia, three senior members of the Khmer Rouge leadership are charged with genocide, crimes against humanity and other charges.
snippet: At a trial scheduled to begin Monday in Cambodia, three senior members of the Khmer Rouge leadership are charged with genocide, crimes against humanity and other charges.
lead_paragraph: CHOEUNG EK, Cambodia — With opening statements about to begin in the most important phase of the Khmer Rouge trials, survivors of the regime’s violence kneeled before a huge pyramid of skulls at a killing field here on Sunday as monks chanted a prayer for the souls of the dead.

abstract: Why is it that some seniors who can afford to pay for what they need — won’t?
snippet: Why is it that some seniors who can afford to pay for what they need — won’t?
lead_paragraph: My friend Cynthia, who works as an independent home care aide in Northern California, told me about her latest client, a 93-year-old widow who broke a hip in a fall and underwent replacement surgery. After two months in a hospital and in rehab, she returned home with instructions to hire home care four hours a day, seven days a week — a reasonable-sounding compromise between safety and independence.
headline.main: When They Won’t Spend the Money

abstract: A collection of articles about the dark side of Vladimir V. Putin’s reign that the Russian journalist Anna Politkovskaya wrote in the years before her assassination.
snippet: A collection of articles about the dark side of Vladimir V. Putin’s reign that the Russian journalist Anna Politkovskaya wrote in the years before her assassination.
lead_paragraph: Anna Politkovskaya, the fearless Russian journalist who was shot and killed by an unknown assailant in Moscow in 2006, wrote about the dark side of Vladimir V. Putin’s reign: the brutal war in Chechnya; the top-to-bottom thuggery and corruption; the lack of an independent judiciary; the “bureaucratic black magic” that could poison, or snuff out, a life at a moment’s notice.

abstract: Mounting debt attributed to inadequate Medicaid rates is forcing one of the last major Jewish institutions on Manhattan’s Lower East Side to close after 82 years.
snippet: Mounting debt attributed to inadequate Medicaid rates is forcing one of the last major Jewish institutions on Manhattan’s Lower East Side to close after 82 years.
lead_paragraph: Her 98-year-old father lies under white sheets, frail and incoherent, attached to a feeding tube and a catheter. But Rose Lauria visits him nearly every day, taking a 10-minute bus ride to the historic block where the Bialystoker Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation has towered over the Lower East Side’s tenements for 80 years, then greeting her father with a “Hey, cutie pie!”

abstract: Nuon Chea, on trial as a former Khmer Rouge leader, spoke of threats from Vietnamese agents as a justification for the purges that led to the torture and killings that defined the regime.
snippet: Nuon Chea, on trial as a former Khmer Rouge leader, spoke of threats from Vietnamese agents as a justification for the purges that led to the torture and killings that defined the regime.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The highest-ranking surviving Khmer Rouge leader, accused in the deaths of 1.7 million people, defended himself on Tuesday by casting his actions as part of a patriotic struggle to keep Vietnam from annexing Cambodia and exterminating ethnic Cambodians.

abstract: Bright-light therapy is the treatment of choice for many Americans who suffer the winter blues, but many experts say it is underused.
snippet: Bright-light therapy is the treatment of choice for many Americans who suffer the winter blues, but many experts say it is underused.
lead_paragraph: Jan Brehm lives in rainy Portland, Ore., and she has always dreaded this time of year, when the days get shorter, her mood plummets and all she wants to do is crawl into bed and eat cookie dough.

abstract: In some states, little known “matching service registries” help bring together home care aides and the patients who need them.
snippet: In some states, little known “matching service registries” help bring together home care aides and the patients who need them.
lead_paragraph: Because a phrase like “matching service registry” can cause readers’ eyelids to droop, let me tell you instead about three women in Oregon.
headline.main: A Better Way to Find Home Care Aides

abstract: A study finds that residents of two nursing homes were routinely overtreated with antibiotics for common urinary tract infections — a widespread practice, the researchers said.
snippet: A study finds that residents of two nursing homes were routinely overtreated with antibiotics for common urinary tract infections — a widespread practice, the researchers said.
lead_paragraph: “As people get more frail and old, physicians tend to do more, when often we should do less.”
headline.main: A Common Infection, Commonly Overtreated

abstract: Asghar Farhadi’s “Separation,” with its deliberate ambiguities and multiple points of view, looks at the complexities of life in Iran.
snippet: Asghar Farhadi’s “Separation,” with its deliberate ambiguities and multiple points of view, looks at the complexities of life in Iran.
lead_paragraph: AS the Iranian director Asghar Farhadi’s brilliant fifth film, “A Separation,” begins, a husband and wife, married for 14 years, squirm uncomfortably in their wooden chairs inside a family court. They are arguing their case for divorce to a magistrate who is heard but not seen. As they gaze into the camera, their faces contorted with anger, the viewer is put in the judge’s shoes.

abstract: The broadcaster, whose father had Alzheimer’s, announced the creation of a center in Houston that will research treatment and care for people with neurological diseases.
snippet: The broadcaster, whose father had Alzheimer’s, announced the creation of a center in Houston that will research treatment and care for people with neurological diseases.
lead_paragraph: Jim Nantz had a master plan: his father would retire from his furniture business and join him on the road at N.F.L. games, golf tournaments and college basketball arenas. The elder Nantz, who was also named Jim, would help manage and organize his son’s busy life on the road.

abstract: Patients, caregivers and providers must work together to ensure people with more than one condition have the best quality of life.
snippet: Patients, caregivers and providers must work together to ensure people with more than one condition have the best quality of life.
lead_paragraph: Anyone seriously interested in improving the health of Americans and reducing the costs of health care must be willing to tackle a growing and underappreciated problem: the vast number of patients with more than one chronic illness.

abstract: A pampered parakeet at the Whitney, and MoMA prepares to give de Kooning an entire floor.
snippet: A pampered parakeet at the Whitney, and MoMA prepares to give de Kooning an entire floor.
lead_paragraph: Museum curators routinely face all kinds of challenges: delicate works of art that need special attention, fragile artist egos that require careful stroking, unwilling lenders who need convincing. At the Whitney Museum of American Art right now there is a particularly unusual character, requiring attention 24/7. It’s Peetie, a blue parakeet that is having something of a star moment on the fifth floor.

abstract: Don’t leave learning to the young. Older brains can grow, too.
snippet: Don’t leave learning to the young. Older brains can grow, too.
lead_paragraph: NEW Year’s resolutions often have to do with eating more healthfully, going to the gym more, giving up sweets, losing weight  all admirable goals aimed at improving one’s physical health. Most people, though, do not realize that they can strengthen their brains in a similar way.

abstract: Thousands of Japanese are stranded near the stricken reactors — many too old or infirm to move — and residents are criticizing the government’s lack of help.
snippet: Thousands of Japanese are stranded near the stricken reactors — many too old or infirm to move — and residents are criticizing the government’s lack of help.
lead_paragraph: YAMAGATA, Japan — Some are stuck in their homes, fearful of radiation, heeding government warnings to stay indoors, cut off without electricity or phone service. Others want to leave but have no gasoline. Still more, those whose homes were ruined, wait helplessly for evacuation at crowded shelters. All face dwindling supplies of heating fuel, food and water.

abstract: Many services that refer families to local assisted living facilities and nursing homes are paid to do so by those businesses.
snippet: Many services that refer families to local assisted living facilities and nursing homes are paid to do so by those businesses.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you are wading into the deep water. You think your parent or another older relative needs more care, perhaps at home, perhaps in an assisted living facility or other residence. You don’t know where to turn, which places or agencies to consider. Online, you find a referral service that can provide assistance — and it’s free.
headline.main: A Helping Hand, Paid on Commission

abstract: A public service message has been criticized as stigmatizing and sensationalistic, but others say its approach is needed to get younger people to take the disease seriously.
snippet: A public service message has been criticized as stigmatizing and sensationalistic, but others say its approach is needed to get younger people to take the disease seriously.
lead_paragraph: The advertisement opens like a French film noir, showing portraits of melancholy-looking men standing against a shadowy black-and-white backdrop of menacing New York City streets. “When you get H.I.V.,” the narrator intones, “it’s never just H.I.V.”

abstract: Clarifying the story of Robert S. Duncanson, an African-American painter who condemned slavery with his art; and two jewelry exhibitions with dark back stories.
snippet: Clarifying the story of Robert S. Duncanson, an African-American painter who condemned slavery with his art; and two jewelry exhibitions with dark back stories.
lead_paragraph: Misinformation has spread widely about Robert S. Duncanson, an African-American painter. Before and during the Civil War he specialized in portraits of abolitionists and landscapes as exotic as Roman ruins and Kashmir glades. Art historians rediscovered him in the 1920s, but soon muddied his biography with legends and typos.

abstract: Smell and taste disorders can affect more than the ability to “smell the roses” in life and to enjoy food.
snippet: Smell and taste disorders can affect more than the ability to “smell the roses” in life and to enjoy food.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald DeVere, a neurologist in Austin, Tex., was baffled. In 1995, after recovering from a viral infection, something happened to his sense of smell. Fresh milk smelled sour, the dirty dog pen smelled good, and other odors couldn’t be detected at all.

abstract: Thousands of doctors across the country are participating in a training program to recognize signs of patients who are financially vulnerable.
snippet: Thousands of doctors across the country are participating in a training program to recognize signs of patients who are financially vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: DOCTORS with older patients hear clues all the time. Elderly people mention, in passing, that they are missing money or that they signed forms they did not understand. Or maybe they can’t find a treasured possession like a watch or a wedding ring.

abstract: A memoir and meditation on the experience of insomnia.
snippet: A memoir and meditation on the experience of insomnia.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to ignore the force of the sentences in Blake Butler’s new book, “Nothing: a Portrait of Insomnia.” Best known for his fiction, Butler is obsessed with the possibilities of syntax, and the most obvious feature of “Nothing” is a lyric and intellectual buffer overflow that results in long, often interestingly ungrammatical sentences, sometimes stretching over six pages. The most ornate of these is adorned with footnotes, a nod to David Foster Wallace, to whose memory the book is dedicated. As such the book draws attention to its own linguistic surfaces in ways that most memoirs never attempt.

abstract: In this memoir, the poet Meghan O’Rourke chronicles her mother’s death and its desolate aftermath.
snippet: In this memoir, the poet Meghan O’Rourke chronicles her mother’s death and its desolate aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The Christmas that Meghan O’Rourke was 5, her mother gave her a journal — a whole world of blank pages, puzzling to the child but not to the mother. Barbara O’Rourke explained to her daughter that the book was a place for her to put her thoughts: “You’d write something like ‘Today I saw a woman with purple hair crossing Montague Street.’ ”

abstract: Two independent films — Azazel Jacobs’s “Terri” and David Robert Mitchell’s “Myth of the American Sleepover” — revise and reinvigorate a cherished American genre.
snippet: Two independent films — Azazel Jacobs’s “Terri” and David Robert Mitchell’s “Myth of the American Sleepover” — revise and reinvigorate a cherished American genre.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to the teen movie, as with many well-defined genres, familiarity is often part of the point. But a pair of new American indies — “Terri” (opening Friday) and “The Myth of the American Sleepover” (opening July 22) — show that the conventions of the high-school film provide a useful shorthand even as they present room for nuance and complication. “Terri,” a character study and unlikely buddy movie named for its outsize protagonist, tackles the evergreen subject of adolescent alienation. Drifting from one slumber party to another, “Myth” borrows the night-in-the-life structure associated with two classics of the genre, “American Graffiti” and “Dazed and Confused.”

abstract: Despite tight credit, some developers are building new retirement and assisted-living housing to take advantage of a market in which demand now outstrips supply.
snippet: Despite tight credit, some developers are building new retirement and assisted-living housing to take advantage of a market in which demand now outstrips supply.
lead_paragraph: EAST NORTHPORT, N.Y. — When the housing market collapsed in 2008, construction of retirement and assisted-living housing ground to a halt, just as it did in most commercial real estate sectors, as access to capital evaporated. But a few companies kept their development teams intact in the recession, and are now building new facilities and expanding their operations. And as lending loosens, they say, they are poised to benefit from the housing needs of America’s aging population.

abstract: The characters in Amos Oz’s stories struggle with disappointment; taken together, they reveal a society in trouble.
snippet: The characters in Amos Oz’s stories struggle with disappointment; taken together, they reveal a society in trouble.
lead_paragraph: In his remarkable memoir, “A Tale of Love and Darkness,” Amos Oz created a richly detailed, vibrant and nuanced portrait of his young self, of his family and of the young nation of Israel growing around him. It is, for all its profound sadnesses, an exuberant account, overflowing with life and with a joy in language. But Oz is a versatile writer, and he returns, in his fine new story collection, “Scenes From Village Life,” to a spare, almost allegorical style, in which the silence around the words also signifies. Admirably rendered in English by Oz’s longtime translator, Nicholas de Lange, these linked stories prove achingly melancholy, a cumulative vision of anomie and isolation in an apparently cozy Israeli village.

abstract: Passing assets outside of probate keeps them private and can simplify planning, but plans can have unintended consequences if not fully coordinated.

lead_paragraph: THE new tax law signed by President Obama in December gives many people a reason to revise their estate plans. In the process, some will try to avoid probate. Others may be surprised to find that much of what they leave behind will not go through probate anyway.
